awd_titl_txt: Bond Dissociation Energies and Electronic Structure of Small Transition Metal and Lanthanide Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael Morse of the University of Utah is using sophisticated laser techniques to measure the amount of energy that is required to break chemical bonds.  The measured bond dissociation energies are key to determining whether a reaction can proceed spontaneously or not.  Although some of these bond dissociation energies have been measured previously, the associated measurement errors are quite large.  The PI has developed new methods that reduce the measurement errors by factors of 10 to 100, thereby establishing bond dissociation energies to unprecedented accuracy.  The species that are amenable to these studies are small molecules containing transition or lanthanide metals, which are particularly difficult to treat by computational methods.  The new data obtained by the PI will provide a useful reality check, allowing computational chemists to determine what methods are suitable for modeling of these difficult but important species.  The broader impacts of this work include developing a systematic database of bond dissociation energies, providing the data necessary to benchmark computational methods for the transition and lanthanide metals, and providing opportunities for the training of students in the design and construction of advanced experimental instrumentation and spectroscopic data analysis.  Students working on these projects develop strong problem-solving skills, which are transferable to many different arenas of scientific endeavor.  In an outreach effort to the local community, Dr. Morse continues to give twice-yearly workshops for high school Advanced Placement (AP) chemistry teachers.

The project focuses on diatomic and triatomic molecules that possess a high density of electronic states at the ground separated fragment limit.  Specific molecules include MX species, where M is an open d-subshell transition metal or lanthanide, and X is a p-block element or ligand, such as B, C, N, O, Si, P, S, Se, F, Cl, Br, CN, or CH.  The molecules are formed by laser ablation of the metal in a carrier gas stream containing a source of the ligand.  The molecules are cooled by supersonic expansion into vacuum and probed by resonant two- or three-photon ionization schemes.  Due to the exceptionally high density of states in these metallic systems, there is a plethora of intersecting potential energy curves at the energy of the ground separated atom limit.  When the molecule is excited below this limit, a dense quasicontinuous vibronic spectrum is recorded.  When the molecule is excited above the ground separated atom limit, however, spin-orbit and nonadiabatic interactions enable it to hop from curve to curve and find its way to separated atoms on a subnanosecond to few-nanosecond time scale.  The abrupt drop in ion signal is readily identified as the bond dissociation energy.  In an extension of the method, a cryocooled ion trap photodissociation instrument will be employed, using similar methods to precisely measure bond dissociation energies of metal-containing cations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has focused on the development and implementation of methods to measure bond dissociation energies (BDEs) of simple diatomic and triatomic molecules that contain transition or lanthanide metals.  These BDEs provide the amount of energy needed to separate the two atoms in a diatomic molecule, and thereby measure the strength of the chemical bond.  This is the most fundamental property of the chemical bond, but it has been difficult to measure accurately and precisely for molecules containing d- and f-block metals. Our development of a new technique that employs a laser-based resonant two-photon ionization process has revolutionized these measurements and has typically led to a reduction in error limits compared to previous measurements by a factor of 10 to 100.  Our goal is to provide a compendium of highly accurate BDEs that can be used to benchmark quantum chemical computational methods, so that these methods can be validated and used on larger systems that are more relevant to real-world chemistry. We particularly like to measure the BDEs of a group of related molecules and to examine the periodic trends in these values.  This effort has led, in many cases, to quantitative and qualitative insights into how these species bond.

During the time frame of this grant, we have measured and published the BDEs of 56 d- and f-block molecules and the ionization energies of 8 d- and f-block molecules, with typical precisions of ?0.3% or better. Of equal or greater significance, however, is that we have been able to study the trends in these values and obtain insight into how and why a group of related molecules develop different bond energies.  In a study of 10 different lanthanide sulfides and selenides, for example, we found a wide variation in bond energies, but realized that the ground states of these molecules are formed from separated Ln+ and X- ions. When we measured the bond energies dissociating to the appropriate ionic states, the wide variation in bond energies was greatly reduced. In this work, we also combined the LnS/LnSe BDEs with analogous values measured for the transition metals and found that the metal sulfides of 27 different metals were uniformly 15.6% more strongly bound than the corresponding metal selenides. We believe this is a general result that probably also applies to larger molecular systems.

In another noteworthy advance, we have successfully expanded these studies of BDEs of diatomic molecules to triatomic molecules. Our first systematic study of BDEs of triatomic molecules was our study of the transition metal diborides (ScB2, TiB2, VB2, YB2, and MoB2).  For all these molecules, the molecule dissociates by loss of a B2 unit.  Quantum calculations were in generally good agreement with our measured BDEs but revealed a unique facet of these species: when B2 bonds to a transition metal, the B2 bond is strengthened.  This is exactly the opposite of what occurs with nearly all other π-bonded ligands, such as CO, N2, alkenes, alkynes, or aromatic hydrocarbons. Ultimately, this behavior results from the fact that the transition metal moves electron density into the π-bonding orbital of the B2 unit, strengthening the B-B bond. In the other systems, electron density is moved from the metal into the π-antibonding orbital, weakening the bonding in the ligand. This observation has ramifications regarding the strength and hardness of metal boride compounds containing the B2 unit bonded to transition metals.

In a study that is of relevance to catalysts employed in nitrogen fixation, we have also measured the BDEs of ScN, TiN, YN, MoN, RuN, RhN, HfN, OsN, and IrN. Surprisingly, despite the relevance of these species to nitrogen fixation, the BDE of only one of them, TiN, had been previously measured. Thus, our results represent the first experimental measurements of these important thermochemical values.

In another study of the lanthanides, the BDEs of CeC, PrC, NdC, LuC, and Tm-C2 were measured. In a previous study, the BDE of LaC was measured. A surprisingly large variation in bond energy was found for the LaC, CeC, PrC, and NdC molecules, even though the electronic structure of these species differs only in the number of core-like, non-bonding 4f electrons that are present. As we found in the LnS and LnSe species, these anomalous variations in BDE largely vanish when we examine the bond dissociation energy to the separated atom limit to which the ground electronic states correlate.

The BDE values measured in this project provide highly accurate and precise values that shed light on the chemical bonding between d- and f-block metals and p-block ligands. They provide important benchmarks for gauging the validity of computational approaches to the chemistry of these metals as well as enabling a more qualitative understanding of the bonding as well.
